question: A 19-year-old male is brought by his father to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of singing out loud throughout the night, sleeplessness, and claiming he is a famous singer. He had one similar episode in the past and one previous episode with symptoms of low energy and mood, for which he received treatment and reached a pre-morbid level of functionality. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with sudden urinary retention and lower limb weakness. The neurosurgeon is called, urgent surgery is recommended after relevant imaging studies. To establish a diagnosis of cauda equina syndrome, besides the aforementioned symptoms, what other clinical feature must be present?

A 40-year-old married man presents to the emergency room with coarse tremors and visual hallucinations. He is unable to identify his family members. When asked about the time of the day he gives an incorrect answer. He also gives vague answers on the hospital whereabouts. Detailed history reveals regular and heavy alcohol intake for the last 10 years. On examination his pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg and respiratory rate of 32 per min. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months along with numbness in hands and feet. On examination, she has a bilateral high stepping gait with a positive Romberg sign. There was wasting and weakness of distal muscles of both upper and lower limbs with reduced reflexes. What will be the first investigation of choice to diagnose the disease?

A child requires multiple minor surgical procedures in the nasopharynx. Which drug has high surface local anesthetic activity and intrinsic vasoconstrictor actions that reduce bleeding in the mucous membrane?

According to the McDonald criteria for the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, if a patient has 2 episodes separated in time and space, with clinical evidence of at least 2 lesions on MRI, what further investigations are required for the diagnosis of MS?

answers.option: Wait for seeing a rise in intracranial pressure to perform lumbar puncture
Wait 1 year to assess disease progression
Wait for another lesion with additional attacks
No further requirement as clinical evidence alone suffices
Wait for another episode as further imaging needed

question: What is the antidote to benzodiazepine poisoning?
What type of speech is observed in patients with mania?
Which cranial nerve carries sensory information in the corneal reflex?
Which of the following anti-depressants has a stronger risk of self-harm and suicide?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the hospital with a severe headache and high-grade fever. Examination reveals he is irritable, febrile, and nuchal rigidity is present. A lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid detailed report (CSF D/R) is ordered. What finding would indicate viral meningitis?
A 14-year-old adolescent suddenly begins choking while having dinner and is in severe distress. What life-saving intervention must be done immediately?

A 16-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the psychiatry clinic with concerns regarding her behavior for 2 weeks. She has stopped going to school and stays in her room the entire day. She refuses to eat food and claims that it has been poisoned. She also believes that her family has installed cameras in her room to keep a close eye on her. She has stopped interacting with her friends and family. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old baby is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of progressive lower limb weakness for the last five days. He has a history of viral sore throat ten days back. On examination, reflexes are absent in both lower limbs. The child is otherwise conscious and vitally stable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old woman, 28 weeks pregnant, presents to the emergency room with persistent vomiting associated with mild to moderate diffuse headache and visual blurring for the last 2-3 weeks. Her last two pregnancies were uneventful. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg with a pulse of 102 beats/min and she is afebrile. The only significant finding on a neurologic exam is significant bilateral papilledema. Routine investigations show mild leukocytosis and sodium levels of 128 mEq/l. CSF analysis is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain is unremarkable, but MR venography showed filling defects in superior sagittal and bilateral transverse venous sinuses. APLA and the rest of the investigations for the autoimmune disease were negative. What could be the most likely predisposing etiological factor in her problem in this clinical vignette?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room after head trauma with complaints of headache and bleeding from the right ear. CT scan shows a right temporal bone fracture. He is discharged after a period of observation. One week later he came with difficulty in closing the right eye, which of the following nerve is likely to be involved in this case?

A 30-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of loss of pain and temperature sensations in the right arm. He has a history of gunshot wounds to the left side of the spinal cord. Where is the lesion located?

A 30-year-old male with a history of road traffic accident complains of severe backache and severe pain in both legs with paraparesis, urinary and fecal incontinence. A lesion of conus medullaris is suspected. Where does it terminate in adults?

A 31-year-old female presents to the emergency room with a headache, fever, and swelling around the eyes. She has had a history of sinusitis for the past 4 months. Examination revealed decreased visual acuity, diminished pupillary reflexes, ptosis, periorbital edema, and painful eye movement. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema. Vitals include a temperature of 102°F, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 130/87 mmHg. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
A 33-year-old man undergoes surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following anesthetic agents can sensitize the heart to the effects of catecholamines?

A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with weakness in his upper and lower limbs after falling from a height. The weakness is more in the upper limbs than the lower limbs. Which type of spinal cord injury is most likely responsible for this presentation?

A 35-year-old man has sustained multiple injuries in a road traffic accident and has to undergo emergency surgery for penetrating abdominal injury. The patient is given rapid sequence general anesthesia. Which neuromuscular blocking agent is given for rapid sequence induction?

A 37-year-old male presents to the neurology outpatient department with drooping eyelids and double vision. He is diagnosed with oculomotor nerve palsy. Damage to which vessel is most likely to cause his condition?

A 38-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of double vision and unable to open the right eye completely. She has a history of a road traffic accident 4 months back. On examination of the right eye, there is eyelid drooping. The eye deviates outward and downward. Which cranial nerve is most likely damaged in this patient?

A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a traumatic spinal cord injury after a road traffic accident. Examination reveals spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Which of the following benzodiazepines has the longest duration of action and is most suitable in this case?

A 40-year-old female presents with right-sided unilateral headaches for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no remarkable findings. The representative gross appearance of the lesion seen on the CT scan of the head shows a dura-based mass. Surgical removal and microscopic examination show elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm with occasional psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever and a headache for the last 20 days. He describes the headache as gradual in onset and moderate in intensity. In the last 10 days, he suffered three episodes of generalized seizures followed by weakness on the right side of the body. He was recently treated for a middle ear infection last month. He has a history of diabetes mellitus, controlled with metformin twice daily. On examination, his GCS is 15/15, right-sided power 2/5 in the upper and lower right limb, and speech is slurred. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting and headache for the past hour. He had a road traffic accident this morning. Glasgow's consciousness score is E4M6V4. Pupils are anisocoric and reactive. CT scan reveals a biconvex hyperdensity over the right temporoparietal region along with a fracture of the temporal bone. What is the most likely source of the blood?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of anosmia for 5 months. Radiological imaging shows a mass in the anterior cranial fossa along the olfactory groove. A primary brain tumor is suspected. What is the cell of origin of the most likely tumor?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after cutting his finger with a handsaw. There is a deep 2-cm long laceration on his right index finger. Bupivacaine is used as local anesthesia for suturing. What is the most common toxic adverse effect of bupivacaine?

A 45-year-old woman on antiepileptic therapy complains of acne and increased facial hair growth. She is on no other medication. Which of the following most probable antiepileptic medication is responsible for the adverse effects this woman is experiencing?

A 47-year-old man with seizure disorder presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. Because of a recent exacerbation in his seizures, he has been prescribed lamotrigine. What is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?

answers.option: Binds to collapsing response mediator protein-2
Blockade of both sodium and calcium channels

question: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. The patient has abnormal flexion on pain, opens eyes on pain with no verbal response. Pupils are equal and reactive to pain stimuli. CT scan reveals a crescent hyper-density over the right frontoparietal region along with the midline shift. What is the GCS of this patient?

A 50-year-old man presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with the complaint of a severe headache on the side of his head for the past 6 months. He also complains of vision loss in his left eye, blackouts, low-grade fever, and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male patient, previously diagnosed patient of diabetes mellitus type-2 and hypertension, is diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson disease. Which of the following symptoms is not typically seen in this condition?

A 6-year-old male child weighing 20 kgs is brought to emergency with a history of weakness in both lower extremities, which has now progressively involved the trunk and upper limbs over a period of ten days. On examination, the sensations are intact, the tone is reduced, and reflexes are not elicited in lower limbs and +1 in upper limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male, with a history of hypertension and diabetes, is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset left-sided weakness for the last 1 hour. On examination, his blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg, his pulse is regular at 90 beats/min, and his GCS is 12/15. He has left-sided hemiparesis with upgoing plantars. CT scan of the brain reveals no findings. All baseline investigations are also within normal limits. What should be the first step in the management of this case?

A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive bilateral asymmetric tremors, which disappear upon performing routine activities. He has no history of forgetfulness. His attendants notice his movements are slow and sluggish. There is no history of falls, difficulty in swallowing, or respiratory problems. Upon questioning, his daughter reports a long history of constipation and sleep issues such as dream reenactments and insomnia. An MRI of the brain shows insignificant age-related changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old male complains of progressive problems with gait, speech, and hand tremors for two years. He also has occasional lightheadedness with standing and a 6-year history of impotence. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. His blood pressure is 140/84 mm Hg lying down, and 98/72 mm Hg standing, without change in pulse. Mental status is normal. He has reduced facial expression, high-pitched dysarthria, and mild anterocollis. There is no resting tremor. He has an irregular tremulousness of both hands when outstretched, worse on the right, without ataxia on finger-to-nose testing. He is bradykinetic and his gait is slow, shuffling, and unsteady. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old male patient requires pharmacological treatment for Parkinson disease. He has a past medical history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and chronic constipation. Which of the following drugs should not be used in this patient?

A 78-year-old man with generalized anxiety disorder and mild dementia visits his primary care physician. Physical examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen are unremarkable. Which of the following would be the best treatment option for his generalized anxiety disorder?
A brain histopathology specimen shows pale substantia nigra and locus ceruleus with neuronal achromasia, tangles, and ballooned neurons. Which of the following diseases exhibits these features?

A brain tumor histopathology specimen shows cells with round nuclei with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance) associated with dystrophic calcification. What is the most likely brain tumor that exhibits these features?
An 8-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents with the complaint of inattention and inability to sit in the class. What is the probable diagnosis?

An 81-year-old female comes to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of diminished facial expression (often termed masked facies), stooped posture, slowing of voluntary movement, taking progressively shortened, accelerated steps, rigidity, and a “pill-rolling” tremor. The first gene to be identified as a cause of Parkinson's Disease encodes a-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally associated with synapses. Mutations in alpha-synuclein take the form of point mutations and amplification of the region of chromosome 4q21 that contains the gene. What is the mode of inheritance of these genes?

An elderly woman is about to undergo cardiothoracic surgery. If total intravenous anesthesia with fentanyl has been selected, then which of the following properties regarding fentanyl is the most appropriate one?

An unvaccinated, 18-month-old child is brought to the clinic with left lower limb weakness. His parents say that he had fever and diarrhea two days ago, which was managed with oral rehydration salts (ORS). Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate?
Compared to sporadic Parkinson disease (PD), PD that is due to a dominantly inherited mutation in the a-synuclein gene is characterized by which of the following?

answers.option: The stronger association with neuromuscular junction dysfunction
Older age at the onset of symptoms
More robust response to dopaminergic therapy

question: Damage to which area of the brain can cause alexia and agraphia?
How soon after a stroke should rehabilitation be initiated?
Lorazepam can be safely used as a pre-anesthetic medication in a patient undergoing liver transplantation without the fear of excessive CNS depression. What is the reason for this?

answers.option: A selective anxiolytic devoid of CNS depressant actions
Actively secreted into the GI tract

question: Mitochondrial dysfunction has been implicated as a contributing factor for Parkinson disease, that is caused by mutations in genes that encode the proteins DJ-1, PINK1, and parkin. What is the mode of inheritance?

answers.option: Autosomal dominant and X- linked recessive

question: What basal exudate will be seen in tuberculous meningitis?
What is another name for neurofilaments?
What is the first-line drug used in the treatment of status epilepticus?
What is the first-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia?
What is the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines?

answers.option: Blocks T-Type Ca 2+ channels in thalamic neurons
Facilitates GABA-A action by increasing frequency of Cl- channel opening

question: Which drug has the capacity to reverse the effects of opioids?
Which drug is suitable for the treatment of malignant hyperthermia?
Which of the disease-modifying medications used for multiple sclerosis (MS) is administered via the intramuscular route?
Which of the following agents is a weak anesthetic but a potent analgesic and thus is given with other inhalants?
Which of the following anesthetics allows patients to ambulate faster and has the lowest risk of postoperative vomiting?
Which of the following anxiety disorders comprises of specific conditions?
Which of the following bacteria is a known cause of meningitis and can be diagnosed by Quellung reaction?
Which of the following can be found in the brain in neurosarcoidosis?
Which of the following disorder is not a risk factor for suicide?
Which of the following is a common variable used for a pie chart?
Which of the following is a major risk factor for most forms of dementia?
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of central axial block?
Which of the following is considered a subset of a population?
Which of the following is not a risk factor for subdural hematoma?
Which of the following is the most appropriate first step in the immediate management of a patient presenting to the emergency room with status epilepticus?

answers.option: Draw blood to send for complete blood count

question: Which of the following is the most common brain tumor in children occurring in the posterior cranial fossa?
Which of the following is the most common mechanism of action of antipsychotic drugs?
Which of the following is true regarding acute viral encephalitis?

answers.option: Herpes RNA is detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
Acyclovir 10 mg/kg 3 times daily for 2-3 weeks is given

question: Which of the following neurological diseases has the highest mortality rate?
Which of the following options include all four cardinal symptoms that are present in Parkinson disease?

answers.option: Tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability
Tremor, bradycardia, rigidity, and postural instability

question: Which of these is the first-line investigation in a patient presenting with subarachnoid hemorrhage?
Which of these reduces intracranial pressure?

answers.option: Keep patient lying in prone position

question: Which organism can cause meningitis in a child consuming unpasteurized milk?
Which spinal ligament connects two laminae and fuses with the facet joint?
Why is epinephrine recommended in local anesthesia?

65 years old male came to neurology OPD, he has complaints of deficits in memory, visuospatial orientation, judgment, personality, and language. Which of the following are the major microscopic abnormalities of Alzheimer’s disease?

answers.option: Cowdry Type A Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

question: 71 years old male came to neurology OPD, with presenting symptoms of alterations in mental status, fever & headache. MRI shows inflammation in the temporal lobe. Which of the following organisms may show inflammatory infiltrates & Cowdry Type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies, and found in neurons and glia?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the doctor by his parents with the complaint that he gets angry and frequently beats other children up at school. He also leaves school at times. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parents. He has been complaining of headache, fever, and stiff neck for the past 2 days. He is also vomiting and has had no appetite. On physical examination, he is found to be febrile (102°F) and Kerning's sign is present. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain is normal. What investigation will be appropriate to perform to reach a diagnosis?

answers.option: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain with contrast

question: A 10-year-old boy is referred to a psychologist with complaints of extreme aggression towards his classmates, stealing others' belongings, manipulating his teachers and parents, and has also run away from school 2-3 times. What is the diagnosis in this boy?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of headache and papilledema. The magnetic resonance imaging of the head reveals a mass in the fourth ventricle. Which of the following neoplasms does he most likely have?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of fever, headache, confusion, left eye drooping, and right-sided weakness for 4 days. He had a mild upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, he has left eye ptosis with restricted medial gaze, 3/5 power on the right upper and lower extremity with brisk reflexes, and an upgoing plantar. Signs of meningeal irritation were absent. An MRI of the brain shows multiple large confluent areas of hyperintensities in the bilateral subcortical region, midbrain, and cerebellum with patchy enhancement. His cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed lymphocytic pleocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents with a complaint of persistent headaches for the past 3 months. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows a 4-centimeter cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere. On gross examination, a cyst filled with gelatinous material. The cyst has a thin wall and a 1-centimeter mural nodule. Microscopically, the mass is composed of cells that have long, hair-like processes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 10-year-old boy requires drug treatment for absence seizures. He has a past history of multiple generalized tonic-clonic seizures as well. Which of the following drugs is best suited in this case?
A 10-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and red lesions on her eyelid and back. What would her muscle biopsy show?

A 13-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of trouble walking. She is asked to stand still but begins to sway. A Romberg's test is conducted and the patient is asked to close her eyes while standing and the swaying worsens. Which of the following is a likely cause of her walking problems?
A 14-year-old girl who took an overdose of paracetamol in the context of being called fat at school is brought to the emergency department. What is the most important assessment in this case?

A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after a sudden loss of consciousness with generalized stiffness in the body and jerking limbs. He is otherwise well but according to his parents, he is clumsy and drops objects in the morning 2-3 times per week, such as a toothbrush, teaspoon, breakfast plates, and cutlery. This has been going on for the last year. His paternal uncle is reported to have had epilepsy. What is the next best management plan?

answers.option: Suspect metabolic derangement and send blood for biochemical profile immediately
Cardiac arrhythmias should be ruled out first
EEG and MRI brain should be ordered
Observe; usually treatment is not indicated in a single seizure

question: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of recurrent loss of consciousness followed by confusion. He had three similar episodes within the last 6 months. All these episodes are associated with the inability to recall the events that occurred during the episode. Trauma to the tongue and incontinence is observed by his family after each episode. Which of the following is the best procedure to reach an accurate diagnosis?

A 15-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a complaint of fever, drowsiness, and fits for six hours. He had a cough, sore throat, and generalized muscle, and joint pain for the past three days. On examination, he is drowsy, with neck rigidity, and a positive Kernig's sign. He is also noticed to have a widespread petechial rash on his body. Which of the following is an indicator for a bad prognosis in this condition?
A 15-year-old male presents with the complaint of muscle twitching in arms and legs on waking up for the past 2-3 months. Which of the following would be your first differential diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a bullet injury on his back. After initial resuscitation, a complete head-to-toe examination is performed. On examination, the patient has loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of his body. Which structure is damaged in this case?

A 16-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of lower limb weakness, respiratory distress, and unilateral facial paralysis. On examination, deep tendon reflex is absent. The level of proteins in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
A 16-year-old female presents with complaints of experiencing seizures after awakening from sleep for 2 months. The seizures do not appear at any other specific time. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe right-sided headache for the last 6 hours associated with vomiting and increased sensitivity to light and sounds. Vital signs were stable. What would be the best to differentiate between the sinister and benign causes of headaches?

A 16-year-old girl was brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever and vomiting for the last two days. At the time of presentation, she was observed to have sudden onset deviation of eyes to the right side, and twisting of the right hand followed by loss of consciousness for about one minute, along with generalized stiffness of the body. Another similar episode was observed while the patient was being examined, lasting one minute. How will you classify this seizure type?

answers.option: Generalized tonic-clonic seizure of non-motor type
Generalized tonic-clonic seizure of motor type
Focal onset seizure with impaired awareness

question: A 16-year-old girl was brought to the emergency with a brief history of low mood, poor sleep, irritability, and suicidal thoughts. There was no history of substance abuse and no history of suicidal attempts in the past. Her parents reported that she was upset about her poor board results. What is the most likely antidepressant safe in that girl?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after several episodes of epigastric discomfort followed by loss of sensorium. According to the attendants, he appears to be conscious but is non-responsive to his surroundings. During these 2-3 minute episodes he continues to make chewing movements and look around aimlessly. He reports a mild headache after the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department (OPD) by his mother. She reports that her son hears voices that are not real, and faces problems making and keeping friends over the past 6 months. She also mentions how he has been feeling low, stopped taking an interest in his hobbies, and generally lazes about stating he no longer has the energy to carry out simple tasks. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old male is brought by his parents to a psychiatric clinic with 3 months history of isolation, poor self-care, self-talking, and refusing to go out. He has a past history of using cannabis. What is the most likely diagnosis of this boy?

A 17-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of rigidity in the limbs for one week. He is a known case of schizophrenia and is currently using haloperidol injections for the treatment of psychosis. What is the most appropriate step to manage this patient?

A 19-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of muscle weakness for 8 months. After relevant examinations, the doctor ordered an evaluation of serum creatine kinase levels. The results show elevated levels of creatine kinase. What should be the next best step in the management of this patient?

A 19-year-old male presents with multiple cutaneous macules, nodules of the iris, and a brain mass detected by a previous computed tomography scan. Recently, a computed tomography scan revealed an adrenal mass which prompted a visit to the consultant neurologist. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings?

A 19-year-old man has a 4-cm laceration of the palmar aspect of his hand. The wound needs to be sutured with absorbable sutures. Before beginning the procedure, the wound is injected with lidocaine containing 1:100,000 parts epinephrine. The rationale behind the use of epinephrine is which of the following?

answers.option: Releases nitric oxide from the vessels
Increase bleeding to improve toxin release from the wound
Vasodilation at the side of administration

question: A 2-month-old male child presents with a history of progressively enlarging head size since birth. His fontanelles are bulging and tense. Which of the following is true regarding the production of CSF?

answers.option: A major source of production of cerebrospinal fluid is the ependymal lining
It is absorbed by the arachnoid granulation
It is produced by the dura mater
Normally turnover of cerebrospinal fluid is 72 times a day
The normal rate of production is 50 milliliters per hour

question: A 2-month-old male presents to the clinic with a history of progressively enlarging head size since birth. His fontanelles are bulging and tense. Regarding the anatomy of the ventricles which of the following is true?

answers.option: Foramen of Monroe connects the lateral and 4th ventricles
Sylvian aqueduct connects the lateral and 3rd ventricles
There are two foramen of Magendie
CSF enters subarachnoid space by foramen of Luschka

question: A 2-year-old boy presented to the emergency room with a complaint of fever for 2 days and seizure for 30 minutes, 4 hours back. His temperature was 38°C. On examination, the throat was congested, and the central nervous system (CNS) examination was normal. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

A 20-year-old female presented with complaints of bilateral ptosis and fatigability for the last 2 years. After a clinical examination and confirmatory test, myasthenia gravis was diagnosed. Which of the following drugs would be safe to use?

A 20-year-old female presents to the ER with sudden severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, she has a GCS of 15/15, severe neck rigidity, ptosis on the right side, and dilated right pupil. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 20-year-old male after a road traffic accident developed alexia but his ability to write was intact. Damage to which of the following structures are likely to present with alexia without agraphia?

answers.option: Right geniculocalcarine tract and corpus callosum
Right geniculocalcarine tract and wernicke's area
Left geniculocalcarine tract and corpus callosum
Left geniculocalcarine tract and wernicke's area
Left geniculocalcarine tract, corpus callosum, and wernicke's area

question: A 20-year-old male patient scheduled for hernia surgery was anesthetized with halothane and nitrous oxide; tubocurarine was provided for skeletal muscle relaxation. The patient rapidly developed tachycardia and became hypertensive. Generalized skeletal muscle rigidity was accompanied by marked hyperthermia. The patient should be treated immediately with:

A 20-year-young man is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state with a history of head injury. His pupils are asymmetrically pinpoint, body temp 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of these hemorrhages occurred in this patient?

A 21-year-old male is brought to the OPD by his father with complaints of social isolation, speaking to himself, and claiming that there are cameras in his room through which aliens spy on him, for the past 7 months. At times, he starts trembling and crying and says, "They are going to kill me," whereas sometimes he starts laughing out loud. He refuses to eat anything cooked at home, claiming it is poisoned. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. On examination, there is complete motor paralysis and loss of temperature, and pain perception distal to the lesion. He is diagnosed with spinal cord injury. The anterior cord syndrome occurs due to which of the following?

A 22-year-old female presents to the clinic in the 16th week of pregnancy for a routine check-up. Her doctor tells her that her baby has a neural tube defect. A deficiency of which of the following is cited as the most common cause of such defects?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, clouding of consciousness, and neck stiffness. A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent cerebrospinal fluid, under increased pressure, with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, an increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content. Bacteria are visible on a smear. Which organism is responsible for causing acute pyogenic (bacterial) meningitis in adolescents and in young adults?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room with recurring seizures for 3 hours. He has been running a fever for 2 days while exhibiting irritable behavior. Currently, he is very agitated and needs to be physically restrained. His body temperature is 104°F. Signs of meningeal irritation are absent. Plain CT scan brain shows abnormal hypo-dense signals in both temporal lobes. What is an important consideration in the management of this patient?

answers.option: Intravenous ceftriaxone is the drug of choice
Regular use of antipyretics may lead to early recovery
Lumbar puncture is contraindicated because of abnormal findings in CT brain
Early control of seizures is mandatory for good outcome
MRI brain is required as next step to confirm the diagnosis

question: A 22-year-old male swimmer presents in the emergency department with high-grade fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A provisional diagnosis of meningitis is made. What is the likely organism responsible for this presentation?

A 22-year-old was hit by a car and had a head impact 4 hours ago. Following the incident, he developed vomiting and decreased consciousness. In the ER, he had one episode of tonic-clonic seizure. Examination showed a right eye bruise and a GCS of 10/15. Which is the most important diagnostic investigation?
A 23-year-old female presents complaining of hearing changes and balance issues. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved in this case?

A 23-year-old male undergoes rapid sequence induction anesthesia for a life-saving surgery following a road traffic accident. During the procedure, he develops high-grade fever and generalized rigidity of the muscles. Which drug can be used to reverse this adverse outcome?

A 23-year-old man has a pheochromocytoma, blood pressure of 190/120 mm Hg. His catecholamines are elevated, and he has a well-defined abdominal tumor on MRI. He has been scheduled for surgery. Which one of the following agents should be avoided in the anesthesia protocol?
A 23-year-old patient presents with loss of proprioception and two-point discrimination on the right side of the body. Which structure is most likely severed in this case?

A 23-year-old patient with a history of severe postoperative nausea and vomiting comes for plastic surgery. Which of the following anesthetic drugs would be best to use for maintenance in this situation?

A 25-month-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of being unable to walk. The father gave a history of delayed crying and was born with obstructed labor. On examination, he has increased tone and power of 2/5 in all four limbs. Which of the following is the most severe form of the above-mentioned disease?
A 25-year-old female planned for elective cesarian section. The patient is planned to proceed in central neuraxial blockade. It includes which of the following?

A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of low energy levels throughout the day. Further questioning reveals that she also has a persistent low mood and a lack of interest in things she used to enjoy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female presents with a 6-month-long history of drooping of both upper eyelids, transient double-vision, especially in the evening, and fatigue. On examination, she has striking fatigable bilateral ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze with easily visible fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness in neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female with generalized seizures is well-controlled on valproate. She indicates that she is interested in becoming pregnant next year. With respect to her antiseizure medication, which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in her therapy?

answers.option: Leave her on her current theraoy
Consider adding a second antiseizure medication
Stop the therapy during her pregnancy

question: A 25-year-old male was seen in the emergency room with a left-sided throbbing headache, nausea, left-sided ptosis, and lacrimation. He has been having these attacks daily for the last 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of intermittent dysphagia. She was unable to hang out more than four items of washed clothing to dry without resting and had experienced breathlessness over the past 6 months. On examination, she had neck flexor weakness and weak proximal arm muscles. Her sensory examination and tendon reflexes were normal. His lab investigations reveal: Serum-corrected calcium: Normal, Serum phosphate: Normal, Serum creatine kinase: Mildly elevated, Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and FT4: Normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of highly variable drooping of both upper eyelids, transient double vision, especially in the evening, and “fatigue.” On examination, she has striking bilateral fatigable ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze with easily visible fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness of neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman suffers from insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. She has been thoroughly informed on how to use insulin and what her diet should be. Furthermore, she is an intelligent girl who understands all of this. Nonetheless, at times, she secretly stops her insulin for no clear external gain like missing a test, and takes in too many carbohydrate-containing foods and drinks that necessitate emergency treatment. Because this behavior is secretive, her doctors wonder what they are doing wrong regarding her treatment. The patient herself seems very forgiving, tells them that she knows they are doing their best, and seems to enjoy the attention of doctors and nurses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this case?

A 26-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with complaints of bilateral lower limb weakness and urinary incontinence for 3 days. She has a history of painful vision loss in the left eye a year ago which resolved on its own within few days. On examination, she has spastic paraparesis with sensory loss from the toes up to the level of the umbilicus. On funduscopic examination, there is optic atrophy on the left side. An MRI is ordered and T2 imaging shows areas of hyperintensities around the lateral ventricles and a post-contrast T1 sequence reveals a large hyperintense lesion in the spinal cord at the T8 level. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of aggression, over-talkativeness, hyperactivity, and decreased sleep for one week. Her family reveals that she has had two similar episodes in the past 3 years, for which she received treatment. A diagnosis of bipolar affective disorder with a current episode of mania was made. Which of the following groups of medications would be suitable for treatment in this case?

A 27-year-old electrical engineer is brought to the psychiatric unit involuntarily by his friend, who found a handwritten note in his apartment expressing feelings of hopelessness and despair, suggesting he might be contemplating ending his life. He recently lost his job and going through a crisis in his family. Which of the following is the most appropriate management step for this patient?

answers.option: Assess the capacity of the patient

question: A 27-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of high-grade fever for one day and seizures for two hours. On examination, she has recurrent seizures, a fever of 103 degrees Fahrenheit, and a rigid neck. There is no focal weakness and both plantars are mute. Which of the following investigations has the highest diagnostic yield in this patient?

A 27-year-old girl stated to her doctor that, "I was walking with my dog in the park suddenly, I started sweating. Since it isn't hot outside, I couldn't quite understand why...then I started having trouble breathing and really got scared. My heart was pounding so hard I thought it might explode out of my chest. My knees felt weak - it seemed like my whole body was shaking, then my arms went numb. Apparently the whole thing only lasted a few minutes, but it felt like each second was an hour. Did I have a heart attack? Am I going crazy? I felt like I was going to die." What is the most likely diagnosis in that girl?

A 27-year-old nurse presented with occupational dysfunction and loss of interest in her hobbies for 2 months. She was convinced that she would not be able to work again nor would pursue her hobbies of trekking and painting. Recently, she broke up a relationship with her husband. She thought that her life was not worth living and had consumed 60 tablets of phenobarbitone to end her life. She is most likely suffering from which of the following?

A 28-year-old male came to the emergency room, with complaints of malaise, headache, and fever for 3 days and now the slightest touch is painful and produces violent motor responses or even convulsions. Negri bodies are the cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites usually devoid of inflammation. Which of the following virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods?

A 28-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 9-year history of recurrent episodic headaches, lasting 30 minutes, at a frequency of 2-4 times a day. He claims that daily headache attacks lasted 3-4 weeks each year at the onset of winters but this year the attacks appeared at beginning of summer. The pain is excruciating and focused around his right eye. The right eye reddens, eyelid droops with ipsilateral clear nasal discharge. Physical examination, lumbar puncture, brain MRI (including pituitary views), and pituitary function blood tests are normal. What is the cause of this headache?

A 28-year-old man falls and rolls along the pavement for 100 m. He has multiple contusions and abrasions involving the skin of his torso and extremities, but none on his head. He is unconscious. There is no decerebrate posturing. A CT scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage or edema and no skull fractures. He remains in a persistent vegetative state. Which of the following pathological findings is most likely to be present?

A 28-year-old man sustained a serious head injury in a road traffic collision. Two weeks later, he was still unarousable, failing to respond to stimuli, with no sleep-wake cycles or any voluntary actions. What is the most accurate description of this disorder?

A 29-year-old woman complains of migraine headaches associated with early onset of vomiting. Currently, she uses ibuprofen as needed for her migraines, but it is not very effective. Which of the following drugs would be ideal for this patient?

A 3-month-old child presents with an abnormal head shape since birth. He was born at term via normal vaginal delivery. The father has a similar but more accentuated head shape. The physical examination is otherwise normal. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows thickening and ridging at the site of the sagittal suture. When does the growth of the cranial vault cease to occur at the site of sutures?

A 3-year-old boy with a reported intelligence quotient (IQ) of 45 is brought to the clinic. His parents complain that he is unable to communicate with them. What is his degree of intellectual disability?

A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a complaint of weakness in the right side of the body. The child has no history of fever. On examination, his vitals are normal and cyanosis is present. On auscultation, a murmur is found to be present. What is the most likely cause of this condition?

A 3-year-old child with no medical history was brought into the emergency department with a 1-day history of seizures and altered mental status. A head CT was obtained that reported an intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient was then stabilized and taken for a diagnostic angiogram, which was suggestive of an arteriovenous malformation (AVM). What will be your most appropriate next step for management?

answers.option: Give immediate bolus for surgical intervention

question: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of limping in her right leg. She has a history of fever, nausea, vomiting, and headaches that occurred two weeks ago. On examination, power, tone, and reflexes are all decreased on the right side. She is vaccinated. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 3-year-old unvaccinated male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of high fever and sudden loss of ability to walk and stand. He also complains of severe body aches and backaches, but bladder and bowel control are intact. On examination, he is conscious and responsive with asymmetry of limb movements. There is hypotonia and hyporeflexia with power 2/5 in the left lower limb. The remaining motor examination is unremarkable. The sensation is normal in all limbs. What is the best diagnostic test in this case?

A 3-year-old, partially vaccinated boy presented with acute onset of fever with inability to walk because of weakness in both feet. Weakness progressed over 2 days to involve the whole of both lower limbs. On examination, he was conscious but anxious and irritable. Vitals were normal. He had hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and power of grade 2/5 in both lower limbs with mute planters and intact sensations. Upper limbs and cranial nerves were intact. What would be the most appropriate test to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Two stool samples, 24 to 48 hours apart for viral isolation
Stool for viral isolation 48 hours after the onset of weakness

question: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with a sudden onset loss of vision, weakness, and paraparesis. A diagnosis was made of neuromyelitis optica affecting the dorsal columns, what would be observed on spinal MRI?

answers.option: Patchy changes in 1 to 2 spinal segments

question: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with quadriparesis, abdominal pain, and psychiatric symptoms for one day. All of her reflexes are absent apart from the ankle jerk, which is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female presents to the emergency room. She is a known case of epilepsy and has been on no treatment for the last 2 weeks. She has generalized tonic-clonic seizures which are continuous for the last 30 minutes. On arrival in the emergency room, her oxygen saturation is 70% on room air. Seizures stop spontaneously but the patient does not regain consciousness. On examination, she is not opening her eyes even to painful stimuli. She is localizing a painful stimulus with both hands. She is making grunting noises at intervals. What is the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of this patient?

A 30-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches and visual disturbances for 1 month. She is currently taking retinoid derivatives for the treatment of acne. Her body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m². On examination, fundoscopy reveals papilledema. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of double vision and drooping of eyelids for one month. Upon questioning, she fatigues easily upon minimal exertion, and her symptoms worsen towards the end of the day. On examination, she has bilateral ptosis with external ophthalmoplegia and fatigable proximal limb muscles weakness. Reflexes and sensory examination are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female, primigravida, a known case of migraine since her teenage, presents with a recurrence of her usual headaches at the 28th week of gestation after remaining dormant for the first two trimesters. NSAIDs should be avoided in her case to avoid the risk of causing which of the following problems?
A 30-year-old male office worker suffers from intense migraine headaches. Which of the following drugs is a serotonin 5-HT (1D/1B) agonist useful for decreasing an acute migraine headache?

A 30-year-old male patient with a spinal cord injury is admitted for comprehensive rehabilitation. His neurological examination reveals intact sensory function, but no motor function is preserved below the neurological level at S4 and S5. What will be the grading of this patient according to the American Spinal Injury Association Impairment (ASIA) scale?

A 30-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in climbing the stairs and holding heavy objects in her hands for 4 months. It was associated with significant weight loss, dry cough, and muscle pain for 6 months. On examination, he was pale and febrile with generalized wasting. Proximal muscle powers were 3/5 with intact reflexes and downgoing plantar. Sensory examination was normal. What would be most likely seen on his muscle biopsy?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room with sustained head trauma after which he developed a headache and bleeding from his right ear. A computed tomography (CT) scan shows a right temporal bone fracture. He is managed and discharged home after a period of observation. One week later he comes with difficulty in closing his right eye. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?

A 30-year-old male sustained a severe head injury in a road traffic accident 3 months back, following which he becomes unconscious, and required ventilatory support. He is currently still on ventilatory support, although he does make his own breaths as well. On examination, he has intact corneal, doll's eyes, and pupillary responses. There is no verbal response, although there is occasional eye-opening, and yawning. He is able to move all his limbs against gravity, but only on deep pain. His blood pressure, temperature, and pulse are within normal range. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male, when leaving his house in the morning, always has to check the door multiple times to make sure that he has locked his front door. If he tries to leave his house without checking his door, or after only checking it once, he is filled with such anxiety and dread that he must abandon whatever else he is doing to return home and check his front door again. What is the most likely phenomenon this man is struggling with?

A 30-year-old male, who is a known case of diabetes, was found unconscious by a pedestrian who witnessed stiffness and jerking of the body as well as frothing at the mouth. He is brought to the emergency room where his blood pressure and glucose levels are found to be normal. There is no evidence of any head injury. What is the most appropriate next investigation in this case?
A 30-year-old man visited a psychiatric OPD with episodic illness for the last 5 years. He is on treatment with mood stabilizers and antipsychotics. What could be the possible diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man whose right lower limb was weakened at age of 9 years after a febrile illness, could walk with a small limp but otherwise well till 6 months back, started feeling stiffness and cramps in his affected limb. The stiffness and cramps are associated with twitching. This gradually became worse and he now requires support in order to walk. On examination, the bulk is markedly reduced in the right lower limb as compared to the left side, with visible fasciculation, areflexia but intact sensations. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old software engineer presents with complaints of intense worrying about trivial issues that interfere with his performance for 1 month. He has recently started a new job at a fast-paced tech company. He has felt increasingly stressed due to long work hours and high-performance expectations. He finds himself thinking about work even during his time off, which occasionally makes it difficult to fall asleep. He also has occasional heart palpitations, sweating, and a sense of dread that he struggles to control. Which of the following best distinguishes this patient’s experience as an anxiety disorder rather than a normal state of stress?

answers.option: Persistent, intense worry that disrupts his functioning
Preoccupation with work tasks outside of work hours
Increased stress due to high expectations at a new job

question: A 31-year-old male patient requires local anesthesia for lower limb surgery. Which of the following local anesthetics is most likely to cause cardiotoxicity and arrhythmias?

A 32-year-old firefighter is brought to the emergency department because of burns on over 60% of their body. Immediate excision and grafting are planned. During the procedure, the patient develops malignant hyperthermia. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the findings in this patient?

A 32-year-old lady presents to the emergency room with complaints of seizures for 3 hours, in the last two days she has had a high-grade fever with abnormal behavior and incoherent talk. On examination, there are no signs of meningeal irritation. Her blood glucose is 90 mg/dl. CT brain shows abnormal signals in both temporal lobes. Which of the following options most likely represents a cerebrospinal fluid detailed report for this patient?

answers.option: Protein 90 mg/dl, glucose 73 mg/dl, white blood cells 38/mm3, lymphocytes 80%
Protein 600 mg/dl, glucose 36 mg/dl, white blood cells 356/mm3, neutrophils 80%
Protein 39 mg/dl, glucose 79 mg/dl, white blood cells 2/mm3, lymphocytes 100%
Protein 246 mg/dl, glucose 70 mg/dl, white blood cells 3/mm3, lymphocytes 100%
Protein 800 mg/dl, glucose 24 mg/dl, white blood cells 498/mm3, lymphocytes 90%

question: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, there is a clear sensory level at the T6 dermatome on the left side of the body. Below this level, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side and a loss of vibration and proprioception on the right side. Motor function is preserved on the right side but is impaired on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man was brought to the emergency room because he had been stabbed in the back during a fight and was bleeding profusely. He was taken for emergency surgery in the operating room. The surgeon realized that this patient had suffered a right lateral hemi-section of the spinal cord, at the level of C8, due to a stab wound. A brief physical examination of the patient was conducted when he arrived in the emergency room. What findings were most likely present in this patient?

answers.option: Spastic paralysis of the right lower limb
Spastic paralysis of the right lower face
Spastic paralysis of the left lower limb
Flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb
Spastic paralysis of the left upper limb

question: A 32-year-old patient presents with recurrent seizures. On examination, there are no signs of meningeal irritation, and the patient's blood sugar level is within normal limits at 90 mg/dl. Imaging studies reveal abnormal findings in both temporal lobes. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

answers.option: Supportive care with hydration and monitoring

question: A 32-year-old woman presents for a right distal radius fracture. She requests regional anesthesia to help with her pain postoperatively. She reports that as a child, she had an allergic reaction to Novocain (procaine) at the dentist’s office. Which local anesthetic is appropriate for use in this patient?

A 32-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of visual impairment and headache for three months. The examining medical student noted that the patient could not see in the temporal visual fields of both eyes. However, her visual acuity was normal. Which part of the optic pathway is involved in this patient?

A 32-year-old woman presents with a right distal radius fracture. She requests a regional anesthetic at the fracture site to avoid postoperative pain. She states she is allergic to both procaine and tetracaine, which cause swelling at her dentist’s office. Which local anesthetic is appropriate for use in this patient?

A 33-year-old female experienced recurrent attacks of loss of consciousness, almost every night before bedtime, variable in duration from 2 to 15 minutes, sometimes associated with jerking of the whole body and at other times total flaccidity. To differentiate between true seizures and non-epileptic psychogenic seizures, which is the best investigative modality?

A 33-year-old female patient needs to be anesthetized before dilation and curettage for abnormal uterine bleeding. Her anesthesia is induced initially with an inhaled nonflammable anesthetic that contains no halogenated carbons. Which of the following agents best fits this description?

A 33-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches for 1 year. The headaches are constant in character and produce a tight band-like pain. The headache episode last for a few hours and relieves with pain killers. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old lady, with type 1 diabetes, presents to OPD with episodic headaches for the last 3 years, which are unilateral, throbbing in nature, associated with nausea and vomiting, phono-photophobia, occurring twice a week for last one month. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old male presents with vomiting preceded by an occipital headache of acute onset. On examination, he is conscious, alert, has photophobia, and positive neck stiffness. CT head is reported as normal. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?

A 35-year-old clerk who lives in a slum area of Sindh, presented in the emergency department with low-grade fever, headache, and irritability for 2 months and one episode of uprolling of eyes, jerking of limbs, and incontinence of urine one day back. He had a history of chronic productive cough for six months. On examination, his Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score was 10/15 and he had bilateral papilledema. Which best possible treatment regimen would be appropriate to start?

answers.option: Anti-tuberculosis therapy, steroids, and anti-seizure drugs

question: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of restlessness, sweating, tachycardia, and difficulty in breathing for 1 month. These symptoms are episodic. There is a family history of hypertension. Laboratory investigation shows a normal level of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) in urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 35-year-old female was referred to a tertiary care hospital with an hour history of sudden onset right-sided hemiplegia and aphasia. Her national institutes of health stroke scale (NIHSS) score was 20. The on-call neurologist was on board for consideration of an intravenous tissue plasminogen activator. He asked his junior to generate radiology requests immediately from the emergency department. Which specific imaging modality would be considered in this case?

answers.option: Computed tomography (CT) scan brain with contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain and magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain and magnetic resonance venography (MRV)

question: A 35-year-old female, a typist by occupation, presents with pain and numbness in her right hand, mostly confined to the thumb, index, and middle fingers. Her sleep is also disturbed due to the pain. On examination, she had weakness in abduction and opposition of her right thumb and decreased sensation in lateral three and a half fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Radial neuropathy at the spinal groove

question: A 35-year-old housewife presents to the neurology clinic for evaluation of persistent headache and vomiting for one week with intermittent clouding of consciousness and confusion. She had a prior history of fever and weight loss for more than 2 months. Two years back she was treated for pulmonary tuberculosis and became symptom-free. On examination signs of meningeal irritation were positive with bilateral papilledema. MRI brain contrast study is suggestive of CNS tuberculosis. The cerebrospinal fluid detailed report is awaited. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

A 35-year-old male complains to his physician about attacks of intense terror during sleep, such as feeling crushed, and often waking up with a scream, but is unable to remember any specific dream. He also feels anxious and restless from time to time during the day. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for acutely improving the patient's symptoms?

A 35-year-old male is prescribed citalopram for depression. He stops taking the drug due to a negative impact on his sexual performance. Which of the following antidepressants should be started in this patient in place of citalopram?

A 35-year-old male patient presents with appendicitis and requires a surgical intervention. He has a family history of malignant hyperthermia. Which anesthetic agent is the most appropriate to use in this patient?

A 35-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of sequential complete loss of vision in both eyes over one week. He had a history of both lower limb weakness 6 months back with minimal recovery despite taking treatment. On examination, he had no light perception in both eyes with bilateral pale disc. There was spastic quadriparesis with sensory level at the xiphisternum. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with vision loss. He is unable to see anything in his temporal field of vision from both eyes. A lesion of the visual pathway is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of pain, inability to close his right eye, and bilateral loss of vision for one week. He also reports fever, and flu-like symptoms as well as a distinctive rash resembling a bull's eye on his arm a few weeks prior to the onset of these symptoms. On examination, he had bilateral papillitis and right-sided lower motor neuron facial palsy. MRI brain is suggestive of white matter lesions. Cerebrospinal fluid has predominant lymphocytes, normal sugars, and raised proteins. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of rigidity of his limbs for the past 2 weeks. He finds it difficult to initiate movements and when he tries to walk it feels as if he is shuffling along. His past medical history includes a diagnosis of schizophreniform disorder three months ago. He is currently taking depot injections of haloperidol for his treatment. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in using his right hand with pain for 4 months. He also experiences paresthesias and numbness in the hand. On examination, the pain is reproduced on tapping the volar aspect of the wrist reflex hammer. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presents with appendicitis and requires a surgical intervention. He has a family history of malignant hyperthermia. Which anesthetic agent is most appropriate to use in this patient?

A 35-year-old woman is having several severe migraines per month. The migraines are disabling and not relieved by low doses of triptan therapy. Which is most appropriate for prophylaxis to reduce the frequency of her migraines?

A 35-year-old woman presented with a history of multiple episodes of unconsciousness for the last few months. Each episode lasted for 2-3 minutes and she had no recall of events. The investigation didn't reveal any neurological deficit. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate?

A 35-year-old woman presents with three episodes of visual loss. She has recently developed an ataxic gait and often drops objects from her grip. On examination, her speech is slurred, and there is evidence of dysdiadochokinesia. A fundoscopy was performed and showed a pale optic disc. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old male presents with neck and left arm pain. He reports paresthesias in the left index and long fingers. He is found to have weakness of the left triceps muscle and a diminished left triceps jerk. At which vertebral level is his disc herniation most likely to be?

A 36-year-old man with no relevant medical history presents to the emergency department with complaints of abnormal tongue motility, which causes difficulty in chewing food. The neurological examination reveals right-sided deviation of the tongue; the patient has difficulty moving it further to the right. Which cranial nerve is most likely damaged in this patient?
A 37-year-old male presents with double vision. Initial evaluation concludes he has lateral rectus palsy. Which cranial nerve is most likely lesioned in this young man?

A 38-year-old male presented with complaints of intermittent headaches and drop attacks. Investigation reveals a colloid cyst in the ventricles causing hydrocephalus. This type of hydrocephalus is known as which of the following?

A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty lifting objects for 6 months. It was associated with significant weight loss, dry cough, and muscle pain. On examination, he had 3/5 power in proximal muscles with intact reflexes and normal sensation. Laboratory tests revealed an elevation in creatine kinase levels. Electromyography showed signs of irritable myopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old HIV-positive male has received no antiretroviral therapy. CT scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage, but there is a midline shift. MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm circumscribed and solid mass. Cytologic examination shows large cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that mark with CD20, but not with GFAP or cytokeratin. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old HIV-positive man has received no antiretroviral therapy. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage, but there is a midline shift. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a 4-centimeter circumscribed and solid mass. Cytologic examination shows large cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that are marked with CD20, but not with glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) or cytokeratin. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old female is scheduled to undergo a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The anesthesiology team decides to perform induction with propofol. Which of the following is a unique property of this anesthetic agent?

answers.option: Low incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting
High dose required to induce sedation

question: A 39-year-old male is referred for a contrast MRI cervical spine due to weakness and neck pain radiating to the right arm for 18 months. MRI shows an expansion of the cord with a well-defined enhancing intramedullary lesion at C2-C4 level, associated with surrounding edema. The given description best corresponds to which one of the following conditions?

A 39-year-old male presents to a neurologist's clinic with complaints of double vision and drooping of the upper eyelid. After examination and investigation, a diagnosis of damage to the oculomotor nucleus at the level of superior colliculus was made. What structure is not seen at this level?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother with complaints of muscle weakness and clumsiness. He started walking at the age of 3 years. His gait remains unstable and he experiences frequent falls. On examination, when asked to stand up from a sitting position on the floor, the child assumes the hands-and-knees position and then climbs to a stand by walking his hands progressively up his shins, knees, and thighs. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy presented with weakness of left upper limb upon awakening. Past history was insignificant. On examination GCS was 15/15, cranial nerve intact, sensory system intact. Bulk normal in all 4 limbs. Tone and reflexes were normal in all the limbs except left upper limb where these were reduced. The most likely possibility for this presentation is:

A 40-year-old boxer sustains a head injury during a tournament and is immediately rushed to the hospital. He is opening his eyes to painful stimuli and is attempting to remove the mask during resuscitation. He is also producing some inappropriate words. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, heart rate 99 beats/min, and respiratory rate 20 breaths/min. How can his level of consciousness be graded by using the Glasgow coma scale?

answers.option: By using verbal, motor, and eye responses

question: A 40-year-old male is taking antipsychotics for ten years. He has developed tardive dyskinesia. This effect is due to the lack of which of the following neurotransmitters?

A 40-year-old male presents with a disconjugate gaze such that when looking to the left, his left eye moves while his right eye stays fixed. A lesion in which of the following sites is most likely responsible for this presentation?

A 40-year-old man was bitten by a snake while working in his field. He was brought to the hospital within 30 minutes after the bite. He was anxious, and the healthcare provider noted his heart rate was 110 beats per minute, shallow breathing, and pinpoint pupils. He was immediately admitted to the ICU, and the hospital was planning the next step for him. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate management in this scenario?

answers.option: Apply ice pack to bite area
Make an incision at the bite site to let the venom out
Keep the affected limb immbolized at the heart level
Apply a torniquet above the bite site
Elevate the affected limb above heart leve

question: A 40-year-old patient with Huntington's disease comes to a psychiatrist for the treatment of his psychosis. What drug will be prescribed to treat his mental condition?

A 40-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of blurred vision and gait disturbance. Her brain MRI demonstrates high-signal intensity lesions involving a short segment of the spinal cord. Simultaneous brain MRI scans show multiple new and old lesions in periventricular, cortical, and subcortical regions. She has a history of a similar attack a few months back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 40-year-old woman undergoes a parotidectomy and the facial nerve is damaged during the procedure. Examination findings in this patient would most likely be summarized as which of the following?

answers.option: No facial weakness but ptosis is present
Weakness of the ipsilateral face movements with preservation of eye closing
Complete facial weakness on the ipsilateral side
Weakness of the contralateral face with the presence of forehead movement

question: A 41-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with worsening weakness in his right lower limb for the past three months. He also experiences extreme fatigue and pain in his limb. He has a medical history of a diagnosis of poliomyelitis at the age of 5 years which involved flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb that improved over a period of time. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 42-year-old female, a known case of multiple sclerosis for 5 years, presented with a complaint of fatigue. She has been taking teriflunomide for 3 years which resulted in complete remission. She was diagnosed with depression and prescribed fluoxetine 2 years back which managed her depression. What would be an appropriate treatment option for her fatigue?
A 42-year-old male after a road traffic accident, suffered damage to the parietal lobe of his dominant hemisphere. What would be the most likely consequence?

A 43-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of fever, worsening headache, and neck stiffness for 4 days. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) detailed report shows neutrophilia, raised protein, and low glucose levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old man, with history of chronic alcoholism, often in his drunk state would physically and verbally abuse family members. He becomes amnestic of his aggressive behavior but felt ashamed the next morning when informed of his misconduct. These events occurred repeatedly every few weeks. Why cannot these events be called dementia?

answers.option: Gender does not favor the diagnosis of dementia
Patient is normal between the events
Patient is under the influence of alcohol at the time of events

question: A 44-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of ascending weakness in all four limbs for 5 days. He was operated on for lumbar disc herniation 3 weeks back and became ambulatory within a week. On examination, he had grade 2/5 power in all four limbs with diminished reflexes and downgoing plantar. Which of the following investigation findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 44-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of mild fever for the past 3 months. The fever is associated with headaches, neck rigidity, malaise, and night sweats. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. On physical examination, vital signs include a temperature of 38 °C (100.4°F), a pulse of 85 beats/minute, a respiratory rate is 23 breaths/minute, and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Serum electrolytes include glucose of 88 mg/dl. A lumbar puncture yields cloudy cerebrospinal fluid with a glucose of 32 mg/dl, protein of 146 mg/dl, and cell count of 3800 WBCs with predominant mononuclear cells, and a positive acid-fast bacillus (AFB) stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman presents with pain in her right hand and forearm, which has been worsening over the past few weeks. There is no history of trauma. The pain is concentrated around the thumb and index finger and is often worse at night. Shaking her hand seems to provide some relief. On examination, there is weakness of the abductor pollicis brevis and reduced sensation to fine touch at the index finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old female patient who is a known case of an autoimmune disorder visits the neurology clinic with complaints of fatigue, tingling, numbness, muscle weakness, and muscle spasms. CSF analysis reveals oligoclonal bands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

answers.option: Tau protein aggregates in neurofibrillary tangles
Perivascular lymphocytes and demyelination of white matter
Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellum
Spongiform changes in the cerebral cortex

question: A 45-year-old lady is having severe toothache and is advised extraction. The lady wants it to be done under general anesthesia. She has a history of diabetes mellitus and taking oral hypoglycemic agents and her latest HbA1C is 4.7%. She also has a history of hypertension and takes antihypertensive medication. Her last blood pressure recorded was 135/85 mm Hg. All her routine lab investigations are within normal limits. According to ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists), she will be in what ASA classification?

A 45-year-old lady who has had a history of regular alcohol intake for the last five years starts hearing voices. The voices discuss the intention to kill her. She also sees the faces of deceased relatives. On inquiry, she also reports disturbed sleep and low mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male comes to an emergency room, with complaints of progressive weakness associated with decreased muscle mass and pain. On examination, there is muscle wasting and hyporeflexia. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is consistent with aseptic meningitis. At what point can postpolio syndrome develop in a patient?

A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a sudden "thunderclap" headache. The doctor ordered an urgent computed tomography scan and the results are inconclusive. What should be the next best investigation?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a fever and an altered level of consciousness. He also has a low score on the Glasgow coma scale and complains of neck rigidity. What investigations should be performed?

answers.option: Lumbar puncture followed by computed tomography
Lumbar puncture followed by magnetic resonance imaging
Magnetic resonance imaging followed by a lumbar puncture
Computed tomography followed by lumbar puncture

question: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with an altered level of consciousness, and fever. His brother reports he has had a fever and neck stiffness for 2 days along with a rash on his arms and legs. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of progressive walking difficulty for the past year. Nine months ago he noticed weakness in his grip with thinning of his hand muscles first on the right and then on the left side. There are no sensory complaints or sphincter disturbance.
