On examination, there is muscle wasting with a power of 3/5 proximally and distally in both lower limbs with brisk reflexes. Asymmetric wasting is present in both his hands with intact reflexes. An oral cavity examination shows fine rippling movement in the tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis of this man's condition?

A 45-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a painful vesicular rash on his face. He is diagnosed as a case of shingles. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?

A 45-year-old male presents in the emergency room after a road traffic accident with complaints of vomiting and headache. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) shows M6 E4 V4. Pupils are anisocoric and reactive. A computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a biconvex hyperdensity over the right temporoparietal region along with a fracture of the temporal bone. The sensory level is at the umbilicus. What is the most likely source of blood?

A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with abnormal movements of high frequency 10-12 Hertz involving his head and both the arms, bothering him mostly while taking meals and drinking water. His grandfather also had the same problem. What are these abnormal movements classified as?

A 45-year-old male presents with bilateral lower limb weakness which seems to be progressing upwards. A provisional diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome is made. Which of the following features least supports the provisional diagnosis?

answers.option: Normal nerve conduction velocity in the sural nerve
Normal nerve conduction velocities in the first week

question: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis presented with a severe headache, fever, and right-sided weakness. He also had papilledema on examination. CT scan of the brain revealed a ring-enhancing lesion in the left frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

answers.option: Start empirical antibiotics with surgical consultation
Perform lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid analysis

question: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of a chronic, dull headache, that feels like a tight band around his head. His headache is associated with neck stiffness but there is no association with nausea, vomiting, or photophobia. He has had this complaint for one year now. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after cutting his finger with a handsaw. There is a 2 cm long laceration on his right index finger. Bupivacaine is used as local anesthesia for suturing. What is the most likely toxicity bupivacaine can produce?

A 45-year-old man, a known case of diabetes with good glycemic control, was referred to the emergency room with a diagnosis of ischemic stroke. He developed weakness in his left upper and lower limbs 2 hours ago. His blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg and his blood sugar was normal. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain showed a right frontal infarct. He had no significant history. All laboratory investigations were normal. What would be the best treatment for this patient?

A 45-year-old woman on anti-epileptic medication complains of acne and increased hair growth. She is on no other medications. Which of the following is the most likely antiepileptic medication is causing the adverse effects described?

A 46-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with right-sided weakness in the whole body. He has complained of experiencing confused behavior and being unable to control his urine. What would be the investigation of choice in this case?

A 48-year-old male comes to the emergency room, with complaints of headache, malaise, mental confusion, and vomiting. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a pleocytosis made up of mononuclear and neutrophils, an elevated protein concentration, and moderately reduced or normal glucose. What microorganism commonly causes chronic bacterial meningitis?

A 49-year-old man presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of the drooping left eyelid. On examination, the eyeball deviates downward laterally, and the pupil is dilated and unresponsive to light. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever on and off for the past 2 months, child has a history of cough along with fever. For 2 days, the child is drowsy and has multiple episodes of fits. According to the mother, the baby has lost weight in the last two months and the grandmother of the baby has a history of chronic cough. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy presents with weakness of both lower limbs. He has no history of trauma. There is a history of upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks back. On examination, power is reduced in both lower limbs, tendon reflexes are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of delayed motor milestones, difficulty in climbing stairs, and frequent falls. On examination, the child was walking with a protuberant abdomen and using his hands to push himself up from the floor. Which of the following findings are most likely to be present on examination?

answers.option: Spasticity and clonus in lower limbs
Distal muscle atrophy with normal reflexes

question: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from high-grade fever, cough, and runny nose for 3 days. Early in the morning, he developed right-sided focal fits involving the right arm, followed by unconsciousness for a few hours. Upon awakening, he was unable to move his right arm and right leg and had a left-sided facial palsy of the lower half. What would be the most likely cause of his condition?

A 5-year-old child presents to the outpatient department with loss of consciousness and a history of recurrent tonic-clonic convulsions over the past year. Birth and development were reported as normal. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old male presents to the clinic with delayed milestones and fits. History reveals the fits to be generalized tonic-clonic jerks with atonic attacks associated with low IQ. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 5-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fits. Past history reveals attacks of generalized tonic-clonic jerks along with atonic attacks. He has a low IQ and delayed milestones. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old farmer has been exhibiting agitated behavior for the past few weeks. He appears restless, irritable and increasingly withdrawn from his usual activities. Over the last day, he has refused to eat or drink anything and has shown resistance to going outside for fresh air, despite previously enjoying spending time outdoors. Additionally, he has developed some motor symptoms including muscle spasms. Based on the clinical presentation described, what is the likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old female diagnosed with chronic liver disease for more than eight years is on medical management of the illness. She is found to have an altered sleep pattern with insomnia for the last few days and is started on some sedatives and hypnotics. After taking the first few doses, she became progressively drowsy and is able to move her body and limbs in response to voice stimulation but is not making any eye contact What is her score according to the Richmond agitation sedation score (RASS)?

A 50-year-old female is brought by her daughter to a psychiatric clinic with complaints of headache, poor sleep, reduced energy, and lack of interest in her life along with suicidal thoughts for the last few months. What is the most likely important feature in her history to make a probable diagnosis?

answers.option: History of similar illness in family

question: A 50-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department with an altered mental state and two episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He also complains of low-grade fever with headaches for the past month. On examination, GCS is 13/15, with bilateral 6th nerve palsy. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 12/mm3 (N- 0-10/mm3) with predominant lymphocytes, protein 110 mg/dl (N <40 mg/dl), and glucose 40 mg/dl (N- 40-70 mg/dl). Gram and India ink staining were negative. MRI of the brain shows leptomeningeal enhancement in the base of the brain sections. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presented with complaints of left-sided facial pain involving half-face only. The pain was aggravated with eating, chewing, and shaving. The pain was sharp, stabbing, sudden, and current-like. No associated complaints of hearing loss and tinnitus were reported. Neurological examination was unremarkable. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presents in the emergency room after a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. The patient has abnormal flexion in pain and opens his eyes in pain with no verbal response. Pupils are equal and reactive. A computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a crescent hyperdensity over the right frontoparietal region along with a midline shift. What is the total Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of the patient?
A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with proptosis and a black necrotic mass present in the nasal cavity. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. GCS is motor 4, eye-opening 2, and verbal 1. Pupils are equal and reactive. CT scan reveals multiple frontoparietal contusions along with effacement of sulci and cisterns. Intracranial pressure can be reduced by which of the following management techniques?

A 50-year-old male, a diagnosed case of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), dies due to meningoencephalitis. A brain autopsy shows soap-bubble lesions, and microorganisms are visible with India-ink preparation. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition?
A 50-year-old man suddenly developed a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during a social gathering. What is most important regarding first aid?

answers.option: To avoid tongue fall or bite insert a spoon in the patient's mouth
His clothes should be loosened and glasses removed
Patient should be turned to his right side
No oral treatment should be given until complete consciousness is regained
Stay calm and observe the duration of the attack

question: A 50-year-old smoker presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in rising above from the ground and holding heavy objects in her hands for 3-4 weeks. She has lost significant weight in the past few months. Upon examination, she had a low-grade fever, but the rest of the physical examination was normal. She had decreased power in hip and shoulder girdle muscles with normal reflexes and sensations. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels are raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 51-year-old patient with parkinsonism is being maintained on levodopa-carbidopa with adjunctive use of low doses of tolcapone but continues to have off-periods of akinesia. Which drug will provide temporary relief?
A 51-year-old woman presents with symptoms of major depression and closed-angle glaucoma. Which of the following antidepressants needs to be avoided in this patient?
A 51-year-old woman with symptoms of major depression also has angle-closure glaucoma. Which of the following antidepressants should be avoided in this patient?

A 52-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency room with complaints of right-sided weakness and inability to speak for one hour. Acute stroke treatment is planned for him. What is the immediate target to save this patient?

A 52-year-old woman comes to the sleep clinic for long-standing insomnia. She is prescribed a drug that modulates GABA receptors, lacks anticonvulsant or muscle-relaxing properties, and has minimal effect on REM sleep. Its actions are antagonized by flumazenil. Which of the following drugs is this?

A 54-year-old male was admitted to the hospital for a laparoscopic hernia repair under general anesthesia. A suitable dose of diazepam was given intravenously, and the patient quickly lost consciousness. He regained consciousness 45 minutes later even though the half-life of diazepam is 40 hours. What is the most appropriate reason for the short duration of action of the drug in this case?

answers.option: Biotransformation of the drug to active metabolites by the liver
Rapid metabolism of the drug within the central nervous system
Development of rapid tolerance to the drug effects
Rapid excretion of the drug by the kidneys
Redistribution of the drug from the central nervous system to other tissues

question: A 54-year-old male who has a history of asthma complains of abdominal pain for 6 months and feels something is really wrong with him. He feels a mass in his abdomen. All investigations are normal, endoscopy is done twice and comes back normal. A CT scan of the abdomen is also normal. What is the diagnosis in this case?

A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of altered loss of consciousness after being severely injured in a road traffic accident. The patient opens his eyes to pain; his pupils are reactive and equal. There is no verbal response, and his limbs extend abnormally when stimulated by pain. Which of the following is the score of this patient on the Glasgow coma scale (GCS)?

A 55-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with right-sided weakness within 2 hours after the onset of symptoms. He undergoes a plain CT scan which was unremarkable. Which will be the advantage of diffusion-weighted MRI in this patient?

answers.option: Differentiation between ischemic and hemorrhagic infarct

question: A 55-year-old male presents with lower back pain radiating to both lower limbs. On examination, weakness and decreased reflexes are noted in both limbs. He is suspected for spinal cord compression. Which of the following radiological investigations is the imaging modalities of choice to assess the exact site of abnormality?

A 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension presents to his primary care provider with a diagnosis of brainstem stroke syndrome. Which of the following clinical findings is not associated with this condition?
A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaint of inability to taste anything on the anterior portion of his tongue. What nerve innervates this part of the tongue?

A 55-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of highly variable drooping of both upper eyelids and transient double vision, especially in the evening. On examination, she has striking bilateral fatigable ptosis, double vision on sustained lateral gaze, with easily visible, and fatigable weakness of the medial recti, mild weakness of the neck flexion, and fatigable weakness of shoulder abduction and hip flexion. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old female presented to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of multiple neurological symptoms that suddenly appeared two days ago. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain showed an infarct in the left lateral medulla. Which of the following would most likely be present in this patient?

A 58-year-old man was brought to the emergency room by his wife, as he developed difficulty in speaking and weakness in his right upper limb. However, he was able to understand what was being said to him. His symptoms began around 1 hour ago. His previous medical history was significant for hypertension for the past 18 years. After doing a physical examination on the patient, the doctor ordered a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head as his provisional diagnosis was that of stroke. Which vessel is most likely to be occluded in the patient?

A 59-year-old man diagnosed with Parkinson disease is initiated on bromocriptine therapy. Follow-up investigations that are performed six months later reveal bilateral hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound and elevation of serum creatinine. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A 6-month-old child is brought by his parents to the outpatient department and he presents with recurrent seizures, infantile spasms, and mental retardation. Upon performing an interictal electroencephalogram (EEG), a pattern of hypsarrhythmia is obtained. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 6-week-old baby boy is referred to the neurosurgery clinic by a pediatrician as she was concerned about the child's head circumference, which was raised on two successive measurements. The child was born by normal vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was uneventful; the mother has two older children with no medical problems. Both the 12- and 20-week ultrasound scans were normal. Since birth, the baby has been feeding well and not crying unduly. He has not had other symptoms such as fevers or unusual patterns of vomiting. What is the first step in the management of this condition?

A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother who complains that he is inattentive in class and seems to go blank and stare into space at times. The neurological examination is unremarkable. What would be the most likely finding on EEG?

A 6-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient department with complaints of frequent falls while running, and difficulty in rising from the ground. He had a positive family history of similar complaints. On examination, he was a young boy with an average build. Gait was lordotic. There was a scar mark over his right Achilles tendon. Powers were 4/5 in thigh muscles. Reflexes and sensations were normal. Which of the following is the most likely inheritance pattern of this disease?

A 6-year-old child presented to OPD with history of diarrhea for about 3 days and weakness on right side of body since morning. On examination HR 120b/min, RR 28/min, O2 96%, BP 90/64 mmHg. He is awake and follows commands. On examination left leg power 5/5, right arm power 3/5, right leg power 2/5, reflexes are brisk on right side. What will be the investigation of choice for his management?

A 6-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, vomiting, altered sensorium, and weakness of the left side of the body. An urgent computed tomography (CT) brain was planned. What is the purpose of an urgent CT brain in such cases?

A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed as a case of Parkinson's disease in the neurology outpatient department. The neurophysician suggested levodopa for his disease-related symptoms. Which of the following statements is true about the mechanism of action of levodopa?

answers.option: Levodopa is directly converted into dopamine in the periphery
Levodopa is converted into dopamine by dopa decarboxylase in the brain
Levodopa is hydroxylated into the chemical compound in the brain

question: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed as a case of Parkinson’s disease in the neurology outpatient department. The neurophysician suggested him levodopa for his disease management. Which of the following statements is true about the mechanism of action of levodopa?

answers.option: Levodopa is metabolized by acetylcholinesterase in brain
Levodopa is hydroxylated into the chemical compound in brain
Levodopa is directly converted into dopamine in periphery
Levodopa is decarboxylated into dopamine in brain

question: A 60-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremors. The patient was diagnosed as a case of Parkinson's disease. Which of the following drugs is an appropriate combination for this patient?

A 60-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of neck pain and difficulty in carrying out daily activities. He has a previous history of falls. Neurological examination findings reveal weakness and sensory disturbance more on upper limbs than on lower limbs. What kind of spinal cord injury is most likely?

A 60-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with generalized weakness, pain in his limbs, and weight loss for 3 months. On examination, deep tendon reflexes are diminished. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking. What is the likely diagnosis based on clinical suspicion?

A 60-year-old male presents with a history of a fall, complaining of neck pain and difficulty in doing normal house activities. On examination, he has weakness and sensory disturbance more in the upper limbs than in the lower limbs. What kind of spinal cord injury does he have?

A 60-year-old male shopkeeper is brought to the emergency room by his son due to his inability to recall names and phone numbers with some odd behavior since one day. He had recently been prescribed sleeping pills by a nearby doctor a few days prior to the illness. There is no history of fever, fits, trauma, or loss of consciousness. On examination, he is awake, inattentive, confused, and disoriented to place. There are no signs of meningeal irritation. The rest of the examination was unremarkable. What is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case?

A 60-year-old male smoker presents with a complaint of difficulty in walking. He is suspected of a case of vascular disease. Which clinical symptoms support this diagnosis against neurological disease?

answers.option: Poorly localized, bursting pain which relief by bending forward
Electric shock like pain involving whole leg and relieved by bending forward
Poorly localized, electric shock like pain and often in both legs
Poorly localized electric shock like pain in whole leg which relieved by leg elevation
Bursting type of pain involving the whole leg, and relieved by sitting with elevation of leg

question: A 60-year-old male with a past medical history of schizophrenia controlled by antipsychotics presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever, sweating, shortness of breath, and muscle stiffness. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male with uncontrolled hypertension, active smoker, alcohol abuse presents to the emergency room. On examination, he is drowsy, able to follow commands, has right mild facial paresis, right upper and lower extremity pronator drift, and has moderate spatial hemineglect. If there is a suspicion of a middle cerebral artery lesion in a stroke patient which of the following is present?

A 60-year-old shopkeeper, a known case of diabetes, and compliant with his medication, is found obtunded and confused by a customer in his shop. He is taken to a nearby hospital emergency room where he is found to have profuse sweating, and a Glasgow coma scale score of 8/15 (E2, M4, V2). There is no history of fever, fits, or trauma. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths/min, and he has a regular pulse of 99 beats/min. Blood samples are taken for electrolytes, and blood glucose levels. After maintaining airway, breathing, and circulation, what should be the next step in the management of this patient?

A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of progressively increasing headaches for three months, difficulty walking, and urinary incontinence. Her CT scan of the brain shows dilated ventricles. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman with diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presented with muscle pain and weakness in her proximal arms and legs for three weeks. She has been taking treatment for her comorbid conditions for the past two to three months. Examination showed 4/5 power in proximal muscles. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated creatine kinase levels. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A 61 years old male came to the emergency, with complaints of headache, photophobia, irritability, clouding of consciousness, and neck stiffness. A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent CSF, with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, an increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content. Bacteria may be seen on a smear or may be cultured. Which of the following microorganisms cause Acute Pyogenic (Bacterial) Meningitis in older adults?

A 62-year-old male patient comes with complaints of slowness of speech, and pill-rolling tremors at rest. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) would most likely show changes in which of the following structures?

A 62-year-old man is brought to the neurology clinic by his son with complaints of walking slower every day and tremors of hands at rest for 1 year. In the last 6 months, he has also become forgetful of recent events and asks simple questions repeatedly. Recently, he started claiming that he could see an elephant and a tiger in his room. These problems have become progressively worse gradually. He has had a couple of falls in this period but luckily did not acquire any major injury. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 64-year-old male presented with sudden-onset high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. On examination, he had positive Brudzinski's sign and photophobia. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed elevated white blood cell count with predominantly neutrophils, low glucose, and elevated protein. What should be the empirical treatment?

A 65-year-old female is brought by her husband with a history of weakness and wasting of hand muscles associated with fasciculation and stiffness in both legs for the past nine months. Motor neuron disease is suspected and a resident is instructed to perform a detailed neurological examination. Which of the following clinical findings is not consistent with the provisional diagnosis?

answers.option: Diminished pin-prick sensation on sole of feet

question: A 65-year-old female presents with complaints of chest pain, dyspnea on slight exertion, and oliguria. Investigations reveal an increase in serum urea and creatinine levels. Ischemic heart changes are present. She is a known case of type 1 diabetes mellitus and is on insulin therapy. What would be the most appropriate American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) grade for this patient?

A 65-year-old gentleman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of twitching and wasting of his leg muscles for the last 2 years. He has also been experiencing progressive weakness in both lower limbs. He often chokes while drinking water and suddenly starts laughing without any reason. On examination, he has wasting and fasciculations in all four limbs with hyperreflexia and extensor plantar responses. What area of his nervous system is most likely affected?

A 65-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic after falling several times in the past few months. On examination, the most notable findings are a wide unstable gait and marked retropulsion. He also has bradykinesia, mask facies, and dysarthria. There is no evidence of cogwheeling or resting tremor. His symptoms do not respond to levodopa/carbidopa. His eye movements are notable for their vertical saccades, and fast phases. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A 65-year-old male with a stroke presented to Rehabilitation OPD having left-side hemiplegia and spastic gait. Which of the following orthosis is most commonly used to improve gait of patients with stroke having spastic gait?

A 65-year-old male with a stroke presented to the rehabilitation outpatient department having left-sided hemiplegic and spastic gait. Which of the following orthosis is most commonly used to improve the gait of patients with stroke having spastic gait?

A 65-year-old man is admitted to the medical intensive care unit for the treatment of pneumonia. On the 3rd day of admission, the patient suddenly develops bilateral hearing loss. There is no previous history of hearing impairment. Which drug is the likely offender in this case?

A 65-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of pain in the lower abdomen and not having passed urine for 16 hours. The bladder was found to be full. His son informed that he was depressed for the last two years and only the day before a doctor had given him some medicine. Which of the following drugs is he most likely to have received?

A 65-year-old woman, with history of carcinoma of the right breast, was brought to the clinic with altered mentation for 2 weeks. Her CT scan brain revealed multiple enhancing lesions in brain parenchyma at the grey-white matter junction with perilesional edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in getting up from his chair and buttoning his shirt for the past 3 months. On examination, no neurological deficits were noticed. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old male has a progressive weakness for the last 2 years. He says that weakness started in his left upper limb, then involved his right lower limb, followed by his left lower limb and then his right upper limb. He had no vision problems or bowel and bladder dysfunction. On examination, he has tongue fasciculations, weakness of all four limbs, fasciculations in limb muscles, brisk reflexes, and positive babinski sign. He does not have any sensory deficits. His NCS/EMG shows widespread denervation patterns. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old post-menopausal woman who is suffering from major depression. Her medical history indicates that she had an inadequate clinical benefit from previous trials of fluoxetine and imipramine. After discussion, you decide that she should start a trial with an SNRI after tapering her dose of fluoxetine. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?

The letter mentions the rising trend of substance abuse in the general population and the intent of the government to tackle the issue by integrating the care of patients with substance use disorder in primary health care. Given the dearth of specialists, the idea sounds promising. When designing the training program which areas would be kept in mind?

answers.option: Types of drugs and their different effects
